unnormalised: Someone asked me how to understand our electricity bill. Well, it's not rocket science, bhai! First, check your meter reading - it should show something like 12345 units. Then, look at the previous reading, let's say it was 12000 units. The difference (345 units) is what you consumed.
normalised: Someone asked me how to understand our electricity bill. Well, it's not rocket science, brother! First, check your meter reading - it should show something like twelve thousand three hundred and forty five units. Then, look at the previous reading, let's say it was twelve thousand units. The difference (three hundred and forty five units) is what you consumed.

unnormalised: Now, the bill will have different slabs. Like, for the first 100 units, the rate might be Rs. 3.50 per unit. Next 200 units, maybe Rs. 5 per unit. So, you gotta calculate accordingly. There's also a fixed charge, maybe Rs. 150, and some other stuff like electricity duty at 5%, plus a surcharge of Rs 20 if you're late with the payment. Don't forget the GST @ 18% on certain components.
normalised: Now, the bill will have different slabs. Like, for the first one hundred units, the rate might be rupee three and fifty paisa per unit. Next two hundred units, maybe rupee five per unit. So, you have to calculate accordingly. There's also a fixed charge, maybe rupee one hundred and fifty, and some other stuff like electricity duty at five percent, plus a surcharge of rupee twenty if you're late with the payment. Don't forget the G-S-T at eighteen percent on certain components.

unnormalised: Finally, add everything up, and that's your bill amount! Some bills also show average consumption over the past few months, which is helpful. And if you think there's a mistake, call the helpline number right away – usually, it's printed at the top. My last bill was ₹2785.50, and I use about 250 units a month, so it seems about right.
